chamber.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":130}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ccs4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3a0i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5B268F54F78E452CBE35A8368BD108FA","url":"https://youtu.be/BYc7E3fybTI"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":73,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":49,"offset":24,"style":"italic"}],"key":"dt8kq","text":" WARNING: Don't tighten them too much; you must keep the cap a bit loose.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cgj8","text":"2.5. START THE PUMP","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2hvs0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70dkh","text":"2.5.1 Once all your pumps are prepared and settled in your growth chamber, fill the media at a high speed (e.g., 200 ¬µL/min) until it reaches the first filters in the trains.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":174}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e4mte","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0149","text":"2.5.2 Next, adjust the flow rate to a maximum of 20-50 ¬µL/min to fill the microchambers.  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":90}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ef3mr","text":"Comment: It‚Äôs crucial to fill the microchambers slowly to avoid flushing your microbial inoculum into the filters.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":114}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jgfd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gis8","text":"2.5.3 When the liquid begins to exit the final filter in your train, set the pumps to your experimental flow rate (e.g., minimum flow rate = 7.349 ¬µL/min).  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":157}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bcc92","text":"Tip: You can visually confirm that the microchambers are filling. Similarly, observe the filters; they will change color from dry (whiteish) to wet (grayish) as they become saturated. If a train fails to fill, abandon it and continue with your experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":255}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"50pjj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"at8ge","text":"2.5.4 Wait for the desired duration of the experiment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":54}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bgk63","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ots8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c8h00","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4qcqg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"838959E36B6811EFB9E60A58A9FEAC02","height":411,"id":500222,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"bfgve\",\"text\":\"Figure 6: Example of a final MetaFlowTrain setup. In this example, there are trains consisting of 2 microchambers, with 4 pumps running in parallel, resulting in 72 samples. Note that you can stack the MetaFlowTrain racks to save space.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":8}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"MFT.jpeg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rfuhcg7mx.jpeg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rir8cg7mx.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rir7cg7mx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7gegp","text":"2.3 MICROCHAMBER INOCULATION (Video: 03:00:00) Video Protocol:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":47,"length":14}],"data":{}},{"key":"88b8g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ghs7","text":"2.3.1 Position your trains on racks (Figure 5)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e940l","text":"Comment : (Video : 3:03-3:10).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63d7p","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dls26","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gumh","text":"2.3.2 Add 40ul of the strain into your microchambers (your inoculum will be diluted 10 times in the microchamber).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":114}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5peqd","text":"Comment : (Video : 3:11-3:23).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gv3d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e605b","text":"2.3.3 Seal the microchamber with biocompatible tape (3M‚Ä±, Figure 1). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":69}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":55,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ae656","text":"Comment : (Video : 3:26-3:48).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be9nj","text":"Tip: Securely seal the tape with a PCR plate sealer to prevent leaks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":69}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3eo80","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4npq9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"5B268F54F78E452CBE35A8368BD108FA","url":"https://youtu.be/BYc7E3fybTI"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"alt":"","guid":"9A1F86756B6711EFB9E60A58A9FEAC02","height":412,"id":500224,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"1e7vu\",\"text\":\"Figure 5 : Exemple of two trains composed of 2 mcirochambers on a rack\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[{\"style\":\"bold\",\"offset\":0,\"length\":9}],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"rack.jpeg","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rfuecg7mx.jpeg","shadow":false,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/risacg7mx.jpg","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/rir9cg7mx.webp","width":550}},"2":{"type":"emoji","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"A2C3C7386B6511EFA79B0A58A9FEAC02","name":":registered:"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1lfgs","text":"4.1 Leaks on top of the microchambers:  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1b0bg","text":"This is often caused by poor print quality of the microchambers, likely due to scratches or imperfections on their surface. Potential causes include:  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2old9","text":"1. Errors during the 3D printing process.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebbpj","text":"2. Insufficient drying of 3D prints before curing or autoclaving, which can cause cracks during heating and damage the prints.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eshoa","text":"3. Damage during removal of the prints from the support or platform.  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9rtqh","text":"Cracks on the microchambers can compromise their permeability. Refer to your printer's instructions and best practices to ensure high-quality prints.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4g2fm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24teu","text":"4.2 Leaks between microchambers:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8sa73","text":"This is typically due to a loose connection. Ensure you see pressure on the silicone rings when screwing the microchambers or connectors with the syringe filters. Screwing should not require excessive force, but you should notice the silicone ring slightly compressing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ipjn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jfv1","text":"4.3 No media flowing into the hoses from the bottle:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":52}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dj4if","text":"This may be caused by a loose connection to the bottle adapter. Check that no air is entering the connection, and ensure the hoses are fully plugged into the adapter. Also, inspect the adapter for any leftover 3D printing supports that could create air gaps and compromise the connection. In general, this issue often arises from poor print quality or improper cleaning/removal of supports from the print.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73tq3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3scqr","text":"4.4 Air in the top of the microchambers:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":40}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"551li","text":"This is a common occurrence, as some air naturally passes through the MetaFlowTrain system. It‚Äôs important to remove this air to ensure the microchambers are filled with liquid, especially before harvesting. To remove the air, tilt the microchambers to guide the air bubble toward the chamber‚Äôs outlet. You can simply tilt the entire rack, and you‚Äôll notice the bubble moving toward the outlet. After a few minutes, the flow rate should push the air bubble out on its own.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
